items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
River levels are currently falling but remain high.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.

Showers are forecast over the next few days and will keep river levels high at the Brokenborough gauge.

We are closely monitoring the situation and no Flood Warnings are expected in this Flood Alert Area.

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

Refer to local authority website for road closures.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 25/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high but slowly falling on the lower River Cherwell. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 24/10/24, especially in the Thrupp area. 
The forecast today is to remain largely dry. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall over the next few days. River levels remain sensitive to rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation.  Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels remain high but stable on the River Windrush following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 24/10/24, especially in the Bourton on the Water and Newbridge areas. 
The forecast today is to remain largely dry. We expect river levels to continue slowly falling today but levels remain sensitive to rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

River levels have fallen on the River Evenlode but remain high on the River Glyme following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 24/10/24, especially in the Woodstock area. 
The forecast today is to remain largely dry. We expect river levels to continue slowly falling today on the River Glyme. River levels remain sensitive to rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/10/24, or as the situation changes.

We are monitoring the situation.  Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

The forecast today is to remain largely dry. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days, but will continue to slowly fall. River levels remain sensitive to rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation.  Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The forecast is mainly dry until Friday when heavy rain is forecast. This may increase water levels again, especially at the Staines Moor gauge.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Tern - Walcot and Rodington river gauges following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.     

No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  River levels are falling but could remain high for several days. We are closely monitoring the situation.    

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.    

This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, 25/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

We are monitoring the situation. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/10/24, or as the situation changes.

The forecast today is to remain largely dry. We expect river levels to continue slowly falling today but levels remain sensitive to rainfall.

items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message:
The Flood Alert has now been removed. 
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. Levels have now fallen below flood risk threshold at the Butts Bridge and Ford Bridge river gauges. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.    

No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. River levels have peaked but will remain high for several days.   

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.    

This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, 25/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.05 m and steady. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.21 m and dropping in response to pumping activities. 

Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Draycott, Law Lane, above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. 

Be aware the Langport to Muchelney road is closed. Please refer to www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates for more information. Weather conditions are forecast to remain largely dry for the next few days.

We are pumping at Huish Episcopi and Westover pumping stations, and are using the Parrett relief channel to reduce river levels. We are closely monitoring the situation and staff are continually checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens.

This message will be updated by 2 PM on 24/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mid Bristol Avon area

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible.
River levels are currently falling but remain high on the River Avon.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Semington Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.
Showers are forecast over the coming days and river levels will react quickly.
We are closely monitoring the situation and are not expecting to issue any Flood Warnings in this Flood Alert area.
Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Refer to local authority website for road closures.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 25/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Haw Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall and high spring tides. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley, Maisemore and Hempsted, and Severn Ham, Tewkesbury. 

Peaks:- Mythe 4.62m Sunday evening, 20/10/2024, Haw Bridge 4.99m Sunday evening, 20/10/2024, and Sandhurst 3.95m Sunday evening 20/10/2024. 

No further significant rainfall is forecast. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 10am on Friday 25/10/2024, or if the situation changes

items.description: River Avon in Worcestershire
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. No further significant rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours. We continue to monitor the situation

items.message:

River levels remain high but are gradually falling on the River Thames following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 24/10/24, especially between Northmoor and upstream of Oxford. 
The forecast today is to remain largely dry. We expect river levels to continue slowly falling over the next few days. River levels remain sensitive to rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation.  Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the Thames and its tributary channels in Oxford following recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 24/10/24, especially in the New Botley area.
The forecast today is to remain largely dry. We expect river levels to continue slowly falling over the next few days. 
We are monitoring the situation.  Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.16 m and falling steadily. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m.

The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.88 m and falling by approximately 10mm per hour. Cutts Road floods when this level is above 5.75m, and New Road when the level is above 6.18m. 

There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30m.

Be aware that Cutts Road is closed. Please refer to www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates for more information.
Weather conditions are forecast to remain largely dry for the next few days.

We are currently pumping at both Northmoor and Currymoor pumping stations, and will continue to clear water from the moors as river levels allow. We are continually monitoring the situation, and staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens.

This message will be updated by 2 PM on 24/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Worcestershire
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. No significant further rainfall is forecast. We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Kempsey Village
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. No significant further rainfall is forecast. We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Severn at Severn Ham, Tewkesbury
items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland remains possible. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Severn Ham, Tewkesbury. 

Peak at Mythe: 4.62m Sunday evening, 20/10/2024. 

No further significant rainfall is forecast. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 10am on Friday 25/10/2024, or as the situation changes

items.description: River Severn at Apperley and The Leigh
items.message: This Flood Warning has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences. Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to remain high and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. No further rainfall is expected over the next few days.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 16:00 PM on 29/10/2024.

items.description: River Ebble and tributaries
items.message:
High river levels throughout the afternoon may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible from 12:00 noon on 23/10/2024.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ebble, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Alvediston and Nunton.
Further flooding is possible throughout the afternoon as river levels will rise steadily due to raised groundwater levels.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and closely monitoring the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 3:00 PM on 25/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. No rainfall is expected over the next few days.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 16:00 PM on 29/10/2024.
